text: I agree!

elements.text: I agree!

text: I disagree.

elements.text: I disagree.

text: Now we are moving to a more substantive debate, where the answers are dictated more by conviction without so much freedom to choose.  Agreed?

elements.text: Now we are moving to a more substantive debate, where the answers are dictated more by conviction without so much freedom to choose.  Agreed?

text: Oh, ok, let's have a real discussion...

elements.text: Oh, ok, let's have a real discussion...

text: :joy:
I also agree that children ought not to have smart phones.

elements.text: I also agree that children ought not to have smart phones.

text: I have two myself.

elements.text: I have two myself.

text: What age are we calling "children"? Are senior high school students "children" for the sake of this discussion?

elements.text: What age are we calling "children"? Are senior high school students "children" for the sake of this discussion?

text: I believe it is acceptable for children to have mobile devices for the purpose of safety, in which case I don’t think a smartphone is necessary, or regardless of the type of phone, I don’t think they should have access to phones when around well trusted adults :sweat_smile:

elements.text: I believe it is acceptable for children to have mobile devices for the purpose of safety, in which case I don’t think a smartphone is necessary, or regardless of the type of phone, I don’t think they should have access to phones when around well trusted adults

text: I suspect a lot of parents just give their kids devices to keep them quite and occupied. Which is one reason I disagree.

elements.text: I suspect a lot of parents just give their kids devices to keep them quite and occupied. Which is one reason I disagree.

text: I'm influenced in this direction not just by the monomania induced by screens, but by the range of research seeming to indicate social media exposure is an important factor in causing mental illness in young people, particularly depression.

elements.text: I'm influenced in this direction not just by the monomania induced by screens, but by the range of research seeming to indicate social media exposure is an important factor in causing mental illness in young people, particularly depression.

text: I would class a child as someone that is not yet in high school

elements.text: I would class a child as someone that is not yet in high school

text: I think even at University age this is probably a factor, so I'm not too bothered what you call a child - the negative impact vs age is a matter of degree

elements.text: I think even at University age this is probably a factor, so I'm not too bothered what you call a child - the negative impact vs age is a matter of degree

text: Sounds like we are i agreement that pre-high school children should not have smartphones?

elements.text: Sounds like we are i agreement that pre-high school children should not have smartphones?

text: I see no practical reasons for a child to have a smartphone. If anything they do more harm than good.

elements.text: I see no practical reasons for a child to have a smartphone. If anything they do more harm than good.

text: Looks like it.

elements.text: Looks like it.

text: Done.  But pre-high children are not really a point of contention, right?  The most vulnerable age is probably high-school due to bullying, fomo, and pressure to present in the best way, such as touching up images.

elements.text: Done.  But pre-high children are not really a point of contention, right?  The most vulnerable age is probably high-school due to bullying, fomo, and pressure to present in the best way, such as touching up images.

text: So it seems everyone is happy then?

elements.text: So it seems everyone is happy then?

text: Kind of.  But I think we have only tackled a relatively trivial aspect of the question.

elements.text: Kind of.  But I think we have only tackled a relatively trivial aspect of the question.

text: So only kind of.

elements.text: So only kind of.

text: Ecstatic .... easier to agree on the danger of smartphones than the benefits of mustard or tomato sauce.

elements.text: Ecstatic .... easier to agree on the danger of smartphones than the benefits of mustard or tomato sauce.

text: But would anyone else keep smartphones off a highschooler?  My children won't be getting one.

elements.text: But would anyone else keep smartphones off a highschooler?  My children won't be getting one.

text: If your child is a senior at highschool and has a part time job that gives them the funds to buy a smartphone and the need to finish shifts late at night, do you still refuse to let them buy themselves a smartphone?

elements.text: If your child is a senior at highschool and has a part time job that gives them the funds to buy a smartphone and the need to finish shifts late at night, do you still refuse to let them buy themselves a smartphone?

text: Yep.

elements.text: Yep.

text: Although by that age 'refuse' is a squashy term

elements.text: Although by that age 'refuse' is a squashy term

text: I wouldn't support it.

elements.text: I wouldn't support it.

text: <@U012U3HJ0FN> at what age would you give a child a phone?

elements.text: at what age would you give a child a phone?

text: If they are like 13/14 you could say no.  However, at like 16/17 ish you need to let make their own decisions.

elements.text: If they are like 13/14 you could say no.  However, at like 16/17 ish you need to let make their own decisions.

text: I don’t think a high schooler is a child, if you try to keep a high schooler from having a smart phone they will probably get one behind your back...

elements.text: I don’t think a high schooler is a child, if you try to keep a high schooler from having a smart phone they will probably get one behind your back...

text: yes I agree with that - in fact, you're in trouble if you have to give commands to 13/14 yr old also.

elements.text: yes I agree with that - in fact, you're in trouble if you have to give commands to 13/14 yr old also.

text: <@U0130GKUGCR> what sort of a sick two-faced scheeming high schooler were you? (are you?)

elements.text: what sort of a sick two-faced scheeming high schooler were you? (are you?)

text: This comes down to parenting, right?  That's what we're debating now.

elements.text: This comes down to parenting, right?  That's what we're debating now.

text: It depends on how they have been raised. If they did something behind my back, I would feel like I had failed them. However I admit there are exceptions to the rule.

elements.text: It depends on how they have been raised. If they did something behind my back, I would feel like I had failed them. However I admit there are exceptions to the rule.

text: <@U012MTPDH98> please be polite to copperbrilly

text: Sage advice I once heard is that you need to be friends with your children by the time they are teenagers, otherwise your influence is gone.  From that point on its a matter of persuasion.

text: I’m not speaking for myself, I had a smart phone that I bought with my own money :joy: I’m just assuming that’s what teenagers would do

elements.text: I’m not speaking for myself, I had a smart phone that I bought with my own money
I’m just assuming that’s what teenagers would do

text: <@U0130GKUGCR> I expect you are a nice person or Alex wouldn't know you.

elements.text: I expect you are a nice person or Alex wouldn't know you.

text: Is it as black and white as the question suggests?  I am not a fan of smartphones for anyone of any age, but they can be useful tools.  Would it be better to allow young ones to own a smartphone, but lay down groundrules? My youngest child bought a smartphone when aged 18.  My middle child bought one when aged 21 and my eldest child has never owned one and does not want one.  At 18 they can marry, vote and serve in a war ... but we can't trust them with a smartphone?  I do not like smartphones; I think they are more trouble than they are worth unless we use them carefully.  But to stop a late teenager buying their own phone once they have their own funds and the apparent maturity to manage one is counterproductive.

elements.text: Is it as black and white as the question suggests?  I am not a fan of smartphones for anyone of any age, but they can be useful tools.  Would it be better to allow young ones to own a smartphone, but lay down groundrules? My youngest child bought a smartphone when aged 18.  My middle child bought one when aged 21 and my eldest child has never owned one and does not want one.  At 18 they can marry, vote and serve in a war ... but we can't trust them with a smartphone?  I do not like smartphones; I think they are more trouble than they are worth unless we use them carefully.  But to stop a late teenager buying their own phone once they have their own funds and the apparent maturity to manage one is counterproductive.

text: I did not mean to attack anyone.

elements.text: I did not mean to attack anyone.

text: At 18 they can have a smartphone, agreed

, attack!

text: No, not really.  So... pre-highschool no, 18 yes.

elements.text: No, not really.  So... pre-highschool no, 18 yes.

text: You've got 10 minutes to finish this one

elements.text: You've got 10 minutes to finish this one

text: In a perfect world, as a confirmed Luddite, I would prefer that smartphones had never been invented.  I would not give one willingly to anyone aged under 18. I think children (0-17 years?) would be better of without any mobile devices ... except books and perhaps skateboards.

elements.text: In a perfect world, as a confirmed Luddite, I would prefer that smartphones had never been invented.  I would not give one willingly to anyone aged under 18. I think children (0-17 years?) would be better of without any mobile devices ... except books and perhaps skateboards.

text: If they are 18 they can definitely choose to have one, but I would suggest that a teenager should be in the position to start making reasonably wise decisions at 16.

elements.text: If they are 18 they can definitely choose to have one, but I would suggest that a teenager should be in the position to start making reasonably wise decisions at 16.

text: In fact, thinking about this more precisely... I am more concerned about my boy than my girl.  Practically, smartphone will be necessary for a variety of reasons at work/Uni.  So maybe good to let them have it in last year highschool, while they are still under my watch, then we can establish good habits before potentially moving out of home.

text: 0-15 not generally recommended, 16-17 parental judgement valuable, 18+ a working/study necessity in many cases.
